Award.AwardTitle: EAR-PF: Mechanisms and Isotopic Signatures of Iron-Silica Adsorptive Interactions in the Precambrian Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Steven Chemtob has been awarded an NSF Earth Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a research and education plan at Washington University in St. Louis. Dr. Chemtob will perform laboratory experiments to characterize the structures, chemistries and stable isotope compositions of primary iron-silica precipitates that contributed to banded-iron formation (BIF). The presence of BIFs, iron- and silica-rich chemical sediments found in Precambrian successions, is tied to the oxygenation of Earth's early oceans and the development of the photosynthesizing biosphere. An outstanding issue in the study of BIF genesis is the mechanism for transport of iron and silica to depositional centers. Silica could have been transported to the BIF deposition site by efficient adsorption on iron oxide surfaces; alternatively, Fe and Si could have coprecipitated as a single oxyhydroxide phase. The impacts of specific mechanisms of iron-silica interaction on observable geochemical signatures, such as Fe and Si isotope composition, are unknown. The objectives of the proposed work are to characterize the molecular mechanisms of silica adsorption on iron oxide surfaces using X-ray scattering techniques and to identify site-specific silicon isotope fractionation factors for each adsorptive mechanism. This research will reveal fundamental mechanisms of aqueous Fe-Si interaction in Precambrian oceans, assist in the interpretation of chemical and isotopic analyses of BIFs, and place quantitative constraints on the role of silica adsorption in BIF deposition.

The proposed studies will provide insight into the chemistry of ancient oceans but are also applicable to problems relevant to water chemistry and human health. The silicon isotope composition of modern natural waters is frequently used as a proxy for chemical weathering; these results will allow for improved quantification of the weathering process. Additionally, aqueous silica competes with other aqueous chemical species for adsorptive sites, impacting the capacity of iron oxide to adsorb nutrients, trace elements and toxic contaminants. Understanding silica adsorption mechanisms in Fe- and Si-rich waters is important for predicting trace element behavior and for developing effective remediation techniques. Dr. Chemtob's education plan will include mentoring high school and undergraduate students on authentic research experiences, giving public lectures in the St. Louis area, and participating in a teaching-as-research program, culminating in the development and presentation of new course content using novel pedagogical techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Banded iron formations (BIFs) are iron- and silica-rich chemical sedimentary rocks deposited primarily between 2.5 and 1.8 billion years ago. These formations, major commercial sources of iron ore, are key geochemical records of the composition of the ancient oceans, the rise of atmospheric oxygen, and the development of the marine biosphere. Understanding the mechanism for primary precipitation of BIFs is of great importance for interpreting that geochemical record. In one possible mechanism, iron oxide minerals formed in the water column by microbially-mediated oxidation of dissolved ferrous iron. Then, dissolved silica adsorbed to the surface of those iron oxides, which sank and were buried. Alternatively, dissolved silica and ferrous iron might have precipitated together to form a single Fe- and Si-bearing phase. These two mechanisms of Fe-Si association (adsorption and coprecipitation) may have different effects on parameters observable in the geologic record, like the fractionation of stable silicon isotopes. The objective of this study was to characterize the structures and isotopic signatures of Si adsorption and Fe-Si coprecipitation in conditions relevant to the Precambrian ocean. In adsorption experiments, we immersed different iron oxides (ferrihydrite, hematite, goethite, and magnetite) in silica solutions of varying concentrations for 3 days. In coprecipitation experiments, we prepared ferrous iron-silica solutions under anaerobic conditions, then bubbled air to induce oxidative precipitation. We measured the chemistry and silicon isotope composition of the solutions and the structures of the precipitates.

In adsorption experiments, we determined that silicon isotope fractionation factors vary as a function of silica concentration and iron oxide mineralogy and morphology. At low concentrations, silica adsorbs monomerically on oxide surfaces; at higher concentrations, the mineral surface saturates and silica adsorbs polymerically. Using Si K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy, we observed that, with increasing polymerization, adsorbed silica adopts a structure increasingly similar to solid, amorphous silica gel. We determined that monomeric adsorption fractionates silicon isotopes more strongly than polymeric adsorption. In coprecipitation experiments, the mineralogy of the Fe-Si bearing phases varies with precipitation mechanism and Fe/Si ratio. At high Fe/Si, magnetite and lepidocrocite formed; at low Fe/Si, ferrihydrite was the dominant precipitate, and Si coordination approached that of amorphous silica gel. The silicon isotope fractionation factor was larger in conditions where ferrihydrite was produced. These results show that a single silicon isotope fractionation factor is insufficient to describe the range of Fe-Si interactions that might have occurred in the Precambrian ocean. Reconstruction of ancient ocean geochemistry from silicon isotope records of BIFs might require further constraints on which aqueous interaction process is dominant. In present-day aqueous environments, silicon isotopes are frequently used as a proxy for low-temperature weathering processes. Both Si adsorption and Si-Fe coprecipitation occur in silica-saturated groundwaters in contact with iron-bearing soils and bedrock; because those processes have distinct fractionation factors, the silicon isotope signature of fluid-rock interaction may be more complex than previously interpreted.
